newsitem.title: USA: AMR sees British Air alliance delay.
newsitem.headline: AMR sees British Air alliance delay.

text.p: American Airlines, a unit of AMR Corp, said on Wednesday that a delay was likely in implementing its alliance with British Airways PLC. due to problems in reaching a new U.S.-British air agreement.

The two carriers announced earlier this year they wanted to implement their alliance by next April, planning that an agreement in bilateral talks on a new free-market air agreement could be reached by this fall.

But American Air vice president of government affairs Will Ris told a news conference the delay in reaching a bilateral agreement would most likely hold up implementing the alliance, although both sides remained fully commited to it.

He said that to implement the alliance, the carriers needed U.S. Transportation Department approval for immunity from U.S. antitrust law, and the department has said immunity would not be given unless a free-maket air pact were first in place.

Separately, American Airlines said a national survey of U.S. international travelers showed overwhelming support for an "open skies" agreement between the U.S. and Britain as well as for its own global alliance with British Airways.

The Fort Worth-based airline said in a statement that 82 percent of travelers surveyed found an open skies agreement with Britain to be a "good idea" and 83 percent backed American's proposed alliance with British Airways.
It said 69 percent said the alliance would help them in making international travel plans.
The telephone survey of 839 passengers was carried out between August 16 and August 20 by Peter D. Hart Research and Wirthlin Worldwide, it said.

The United States last week called off open skies aviation talks with Britain, saying the two sides were too far apart on key issues for productive talks, but a Transportation Department official said Wednesday that the U.S. government was again ready to resume talks, although an accord might be reached with France first.
Britain has balked at opening London Heathrow airport, the base of British Airways, to more flights by U.S. carriers.

"This survey clearly demonstrates how important a U.S.-U.K. open skies agreement and the American-BA alliance is to international travelers," Will Ris, Vice President of Government Affairs for American Airlines, said in a statement released with the survey results.
The poll had a margin of error of 3.7 percent, the airline said.
